article.title: Rebecca Sugar
article.text:
{{short description|American animator and screenwriter}} {{Infobox person | name = Rebecca Sugar | birth_name = | image = Rebecca Sugar Speaking at New York Comic Con 2014 - Peter Dzubay (cropped).jpeg | caption = Sugar at the 2014 [[New York Comic Con]] | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1987|7|9}} | birth_place = [[Silver Spring, Maryland]], U.S. | alma_mater = [[School of Visual Arts]] | occupation = {{flatlist| *Animator *storyboard artist *writer *producer *songwriter}} | years_active = 2009−present | partner = [[Ian Jones-Quartey]]
(2008–present) | website = }} '''Rebecca Sugar''' (born July 9, 1987) is an American animator, screenwriter, producer, and singer/songwriter. She is the creator of the [[Cartoon Network]] series ''[[Steven Universe]]'', which has made her the first woman to independently create a series for the network.{{cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/pictures/mfl45edfge/rebecca-sugar/|title=Rebecca Sugar – 30 Under 30: Hollywood|date=December 17, 2012|work=[[Forbes]]|accessdate=April 21, 2013}} Sugar was formerly a writer and storyboard artist on the animated television series ''[[Adventure Time]]'', until 2013. Her work on the two series has earned her six [[Primetime Emmy Award]] nominations.{{cite web|url=https://www.emmys.com/bios/rebecca-sugar|title=Rebecca Sugar|website=Television Academy|accessdate=22 May 2019}} ==Early life== Sugar was raised in the Sligo Park Hills area of [[Silver Spring, Maryland]]. She simultaneously attended [[Montgomery Blair High School]] and the Visual Arts Center at [[Albert Einstein High School]]{{cite news |title= 'Steven Universe' creator Rebecca Sugar is a Cartoon Network trailblazer |work= The Washington Post |first= Michael |last= Cavna |date= November 1, 2013 |url= https://www.washingtonpost.com/entertainment/tv/steven-universe-creator-rebecca-sugar-is-an-idealistic-trailblazer/2013/11/01/fe622da2-4338-11e3-a751-f032898f2dbc_story.html }} (where she was an arts semifinalist in the Presidential Scholar competition,{{cite web | url=http://www.montgomeryschoolsmd.org/press/printPress.aspx?id=1647 | title=Two Students are Named Presidential Scholars | website= montgomeryschoolsmd.org | date=May 10, 2005 | accessdate=October 22, 2016}} and won Montgomery County's prestigious Ida F. Haimovicz Visual Arts Award),{{cite web| last1=French|first1= Esther|title= Successful Animator Credits Einstein’s Visual Arts Center|url=https://patch.com/maryland/wheaton-md/successful-animator-credits-einstein-s-visual-arts-center|publisher=[[Patch Media]]|accessdate=April 25, 2017|date= January 14, 2013}} both of which are located in Maryland. While at Blair, she drew several comics (called "The Strip" for the school's newspaper, ''Silver Chips'') which won first place for comics in the Newspaper Individual Writing and Editing Contest. "The Strip" ran a comic challenging MCPS's new grading policy from 2005.{{cite web|url= http://silverchips.mbhs.edu/story/5887|accessdate=October 19, 2017|publisher=Silver Chips Online|title=Silver Chips, Silver Chips Online, Silver Quill win in journalism competitions| author=Goldstein, Jordan|author2=Sekaran, Adith|date=November 14, 2005}} She went on to attend the [[School of Visual Arts]] in New York.{{cite web|last1=Amidi|first1=Amid|title=Rebecca Sugar Is Cartoon Network’s First Solo Woman Show Creator|url=http://www.cartoonbrew.com/ideas-commentary/rebecca-sugar-is-cartoon-networks-first-solo-woman-show-creator-71157.html|publisher= CartoonBrew|accessdate=June 11, 2014|date=October 5, 2012}} According to Sugar's father Rob, Rebecca Sugar and her younger brother Steven were raised with what he called "[[Jewish]] sensibilities". Both siblings observe the lighting of [[Hanukkah]] candles with their parents via [[Skype]].{{Cite web| url = http://www.templemicah.org/newsfolder/newsitems/rebecca-sugar-takes-hollywood-by-storm-with-hit-cartoon-show-steven-universe/| title = Rebecca Sugar takes Hollywood by storm with hit cartoon show 'Steven Universe'| website = Temple Micah| access-date = March 1, 2016| date = May–June 2014| author = Moskowitz, Dan| deadurl = yes| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20160305024914/http://www.templemicah.org/newsfolder/newsitems/rebecca-sugar-takes-hollywood-by-storm-with-hit-cartoon-show-steven-universe| archivedate = March 5, 2016}} ==Personal life== In February 2016, [[Ian Jones-Quartey]] confirmed via [[Twitter]] that he and Sugar were in a romantic relationship; at the time of the tweet, the two had been together for eight years.{{cite web|url=https://twitter.com/ianjq/status/698723352819576832|title=ian jq on Twitter: "@CreeperGuy1337 yeah! We've been together over 8 years now"|date=February 13, 2016}} He added that they met when Sugar was at the [[School of Visual Arts]] in New York. In July 2016, Sugar said at a [[San Diego Comic-Con]] panel that the [[LGBT]] themes in ''[[Steven Universe]]'' are in large part based on her own experience as a [[bisexual]] woman.{{cite news|url=http://www.autostraddle.com/rebecca-sugar-is-bisexual-steven-universe-creator-comes-out-at-comic-con-346094/|title=Rebecca Sugar is Bisexual: "Steven Universe" Creator Comes Out at Comic-Con {{!}} Autostraddle|last1=Mey|date=22 July 2016|work=[[Autostraddle]]|accessdate=22 July 2016}} In a July 2018 interview on [[NPR]],{{cite news|url=https://the1a.org/audio/#/shows/2018-07-09/the-mind-behind-americas-most-empathetic-cartoon/114886/|title=The Mind Behind America's Most Empathetic Cartoon|last1=Johnson|first1=Joshua|work=1A|accessdate=13 July 2018|publisher=NPR}} Sugar said that she created the series's Gems as "[[non-binary]] women" in order to express herself, as a non-binary woman, through them.{{cite news|url=https://io9.gizmodo.com/steven-universes-rebecca-sugar-on-how-she-expresses-her-1827624015|title=Steven Universe's Rebecca Sugar Comes Out as Gender Nonbinary|last1=Pulliam-Moore|first1=Charles|date=16 July 2018|work=io9|accessdate=17 July 2018}} As of 2019, Sugar uses both "she/her" and "they/them" pronouns.{{Cite web|url=https://twitter.com/rebeccasugar?lang=en|title=Rebecca Sugar (@rebeccasugar)|website=Twitter|access-date=2019-01-14}} ==Career== === Early work === During her time at the [[School of Visual Arts]], Sugar directed short animated films, including ''Johnny Noodleneck'' (2008).{{Cite news|url=https://hornet.com/stories/rebecca-sugar-before-steven-universe/|title=The Weird, Heartbreaking Pre-'Steven Universe' Work of Rebecca Sugar|date=2016-02-20|work=Hornet Stories|access-date=2018-10-25}} In 2009, she wrote and animated ''Singles'', in which frequent collaborator [[Ian Jones-Quartey]] acted as an assistant animator, assistant inker and voice actor on the project, while Sugar's brother Steven Sugar acted as an assistant colorist. Sugar completed this film as her thesis. Sugar also played an important role in the creation of ''nockFORCE'', a cartoon series created by [[Ian Jones-Quartey]] and Jim Gisriel and launched in 2007 on [[YouTube]]. In particular, she contributed to the cartoon's backgrounds and characters.{{Cite news|url=https://twitter.com/ianjq/status/636312476930314244|title=ianjq on Twitter: "actually Rebecca helped a number of things in nockFORCE..."|last=|first=|date=|work=Twitter|access-date=2018-10-28}} In 2010, Sugar published her first graphic novel, ''Pug Davis'', featuring an astronaut dog and his gay sidekick Blouse.{{Cite web|url=http://archives.frederatorblogs.com/adventure_time/2010/12/09/rebecca-sugars-pug-davis/|title=Rebecca Sugar’s "Pug Davis"|website=The Adventure Time Blog|date=December 9, 2018 |publisher=Frederator Studios Blogs|access-date=2018-10-25}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/12673887-pug-davis|title=Pug Davis|work=[[Goodreads]]|access-date=2018-10-28}} She is also known for her comic "Don't Cry for Me, I'm Already Dead", a story about two brothers whose shared love of ''[[The Simpsons]]'' takes a tragic turn. === Television === Sugar first joined the crew of ''[[Adventure Time]]'' as a [[storyboard]] revisionist during the show's [[Adventure Time (season 1)|first season]].Ward, Pendleton (2011). "Rainy Day Daydream" [Animatic commentary track], ''Adventure Time'' Season One [DVD], Los Angeles, CA: [[Cartoon Network]]. Due to the quality of her work, within a month of being hired she was promoted to a storyboard artist, making her debut during the production of the [[Adventure Time (season 2)|second season]]. Her first episode was "[[It Came from the Nightosphere]]".{{cite web|last=Seibert|first=Fred|title=Rebecca Sugar’s First Board (Nightosphere)|url=http://archives.frederatorblogs.com/adventure_time/2010/10/11/rebecca-sugars-first-board-nightosphere/|publisher=[[Frederator Studios]]|accessdate=January 19, 2013|date=October 11, 2010}} Production for ''[[Steven Universe]]'' began while Sugar was still working on ''Adventure Time''. She continued working on ''[[Adventure Time]]'' until the show's [[Adventure Time (season 5)|fifth season]], whereupon she left in order to focus on ''Steven Universe''. Her last episode for ''[[Adventure Time]]'' was "[[Simon & Marcy]]"; following that episode, working on both series simultaneously "became impossible to do". She had also previously encountered difficulty in the production of the ''[[Adventure Time]]'' episode "[[Bad Little Boy]]".{{cite web|url=http://www.indiewire.com/article/television/adventure-time-writer-rebecca-sugar-on-steven-universe|title=''Adventure Time'' Writer Rebecca Sugar on ''Steven Universe'', Being Cartoon Network's First Female Show Creator And Why Pop Art Is 'Offensive'|publisher=[[Indiewire]]|date=2013-11-01|accessdate=2013-11-25|last=Kohn|first=Eric|page=1}} Sugar returned temporarily to write the song "Everything Stays" for the [[Adventure Time (season 7)|seventh season]] miniseries "[[Stakes (miniseries)|Stakes]]".{{cite web|title=[Olivia Olson confirms when 'Stakes' will air]|url=https://instagram.com/p/4-ChaHhw-D/|publisher=[[Instagram]]|date=July 10, 2015}} She has been [[executive producer]] for ''Steven Universe'' for its entire run, and a storyboard artist for several of its episodes; the series premiered on November 4, 2013. She directed the full-length [[television movie]] taking place after the fifth season of ''Steven Universe'', called ''[[Steven Universe: The Movie]]'', which premiered on September 2, 2019 on Cartoon Network.{{Cite news|url=https://www.denofgeek.com/us/movies/steven-universe/275083/steven-universe-the-movie-release-date|title='Steven Universe: The Movie Release Date|date=2019-01-21|work=Den of Geek|access-date=2019-01-21}} === Themes === Sugar has discussed the importance of creating [[LGBT]] representation and content, especially in children's entertainment. On [[Cameron Esposito]]'s podcast QUEERY, Sugar stated "I want to champion [[LGBT|LGBTQIA]], all of it, content...in G-Rated, family entertainment. I want to do that forever".{{Cite web|url=https://www.earwolf.com/episode/rebecca-sugar/|title=Rebecca Sugar, episode #13 of Queery with Cameron Esposito on Earwolf|website=www.earwolf.com|access-date=2018-10-29}} She also explained how ''Steven Universe'' has helped her come to terms with her own identity as [[Bisexuality|bisexual]] and non-binary. She believes that early and positive exposure to the [[LGBT community]] can help [[queer]] identifying children avoid experiencing shame in their own identities.{{Cite web|url=http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/herocomplex/la-et-hc-rebecca-sugar-steven-universe-20180524-story.html|title=Rebecca Sugar’s commitment to LGBTQ visibility continues to drive 'Steven Universe' - Los Angeles Times|last=Brown|first=Tracy|website=latimes.com|access-date=2018-10-29}}{{Cite news|url=https://ew.com/tv/2018/08/13/steven-universe-rebecca-sugar-lgbtq-cartoons/|title='Steven Universe' creator is doing more for LGBTQ visibility than you might know|work=EW.com|access-date=2018-10-29}} === Other work === Sugar designed the album cover of ''[[True Romance (Estelle album)|True Romance]]'' for [[Estelle (musician)|Estelle]], the voice of Garnet on ''Steven Universe''.{{cite tweet |user=rebeccasugar |number=568989205931663360 |date=20 February 2015 |title=Ahh!!! Completely surreal experience of seeing my album artwork for Estelle's new album True Romance… http://instagram.com/p/zWX0QRqBox/ }} In December 2016, comic book publisher ''Youth in Decline'' featured Sugar's sketches and story notes for her unpublished comic ''Margo in Bed'' as issue #14 of the art/comics anthology series ''Frontier''.{{cite web|title=[Frontier #14: Rebecca Sugar]|url=http://www.youthindecline.com/product/frontier-14-rebecca-sugar}} In 2018, Sugar was featured on [[Gallant (singer)|Gallant]]'s 2018 R&B/Soul track ''TOOGOODTOBETRUE'', along with [[Sufjan Stevens]].{{Citation|last=Gallant|title=Gallant - TOOGOODTOBETRUE feat. Sufjan Stevens & Rebecca Sugar (Audio)|date=2018-09-20|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=p_hIJ1bBtfc|access-date=2018-10-28}} ==Accolades== ===''Adventure Time''=== Rebecca Sugar's work on ''[[Adventure Time]]'' gained [[Primetime Emmy Award for Short-format Animation]] nominations for the episode "[[It Came from the Nightosphere]]" in 2011 and for the episode "[[Simon & Marcy]]" in 2013.{{Cite news|url=https://www.emmys.com/shows/adventure-time|title=Adventure Time {{!}} Television Academy|last=|first=|date=|work=Television Academy|access-date=2018-10-24}} The show also earned multiple [[Annie Award]] nominations. These included, Best Storyboarding in a Television Production in 2012{{Cite web|url=https://annieawards.org/legacy/39th-annie-awards|title=39th Annual Annie Awards|last=|first=|date=|website=annieawards.org|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-10-24}} and Story-boarding in an Animated Television Production in 2013.{{Cite web|url=https://annieawards.org/legacy/40th-annie-awards|title=40th Annual Annie Awards|last=|first=|date=|website=annieawards.org|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-10-24}} ===''Steven Universe''=== {{main|Steven Universe#Awards and nominations}} For ''[[Steven Universe]]'', Sugar has been nominated for several media industry awards, including four [[Primetime Emmy Awards]]. She and the series have received, among others, the 2018 [[Peabody Award]] for Children’s & Youth Programming and the 2019 [[GLAAD Media Award]] for Outstanding Kids & Family Program; in 2015 the series was named to the [[James Tiptree Jr. Award]] Honor List. === Honors === In 2012, ''[[Forbes]]'' magazine included her on its "30 Under 30 in Entertainment" list, noting that she was responsible for writing "many of the best episodes" of ''[[Adventure Time]]''. ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]'' included Sugar in "Hollywood's New Leaders 2016: The Creatives", a list celebrating upcoming filmmakers, show-runners and creators in both [[old media|traditional]] and [[digital media]].{{Cite news|url=https://variety.com/2016/film/spotlight/varietys-new-leaders-2016-the-creatives-1201893079/|title=Hollywood’s New Leaders 2016: The Creatives|last=Staff|first=Variety|date=2016-10-19|work=Variety|access-date=2018-10-24}} ==Filmography== {| class="wikitable" |- !
